claim: Humanity is past the event horizon: the AI takeoff has started and we are close to building digital superintelligence—current systems already exceed people in many ways and are significantly amplifying human output, so the least-likely technical barriers have largely been overcome.
explanation: Partly true but overstated. It is correct that modern AI already exceeds humans on many narrow tasks (e.g., protein‑structure prediction and some professional/exam benchmarks) and can materially amplify human output (e.g., AlphaFold’s impact; GPT‑4 exam performance; GitHub Copilot productivity gains). ([wired.com](https://www.wired.com/story/deepmind-protein-folding-database?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08774?utm_source=chatgpt.com))  However, the claim that an irreversible “event horizon” has passed and that we are close to digital superintelligence is speculative and disputed: many AI researchers give widely varying timelines for AGI and do not agree we are imminently at superintelligence. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.02843?utm_source=chatgpt.com))  Crucially, hard safety/technical problems—hallucinations, robustness, deceptive or “alignment‑faking” behaviours and other alignment/assurance gaps—remain active research challenges and are not resolved, so key low‑probability/“least‑likely” barriers have not been demonstrably “largely overcome.” ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.11817?utm_source=chatgpt.com))  In sum: strong evidence for major narrow‑domain progress and amplification, but insufficient evidence that a takeoff past an irreversible event horizon or near‑term arrival of digital superintelligence has already occurred.
